Professor Krugman has consistently predicted economic and capital markets developments correctly over the past decade. He worried about a housing bubble well before the markets did, and he correctly predicted the current liquidity trap and the persistence of low interest rates.

If you want to make money following interest rate movements, you could do pretty well by following Krugman's prognostications.

Surely not a good idea to go to war on the basis of emotion and literary appreciation - but by his own admission Paul Ryan, much admired by Brooks and the primary congressional spokesman for the GOP's economic program, bases his political project primarily on "moral emotion" rooted in literary appreciation - i.e. the fervent idealism and uncompromising "morality" of Ayn Rand's "Atlas Shrugged."

Perhaps this is who Brooks had in mind.

What I often see in David Brooks's writing is someone who has some sense that the current approach to politics, and even life, in our culture needs reform, but who lacks the wherewithal to see what is actually missing and what would actually help, and instead advocates reform that just intensifies part of what contributes to the problem.  For example, pragmatism by itself may be inadequate but his response of moral emotionalism is not the resolution (it seems to me).  Reading DB's approach for me can be like watching someone who doesn't know they are colorblind trying to teach their own workarounds to others.  I suspect that to a similar degree he finds our president's approach frustrating, I find his approach frustrating, even if the details of the frustrations are different.
Again, Mr. Freeman is the voice of reason.

Gosh, when David Brooks goes for a "think piece" as opposed to an obvious screed on the virtues of conservative politics he comes across as even more inane than usual.  He would have our agenda as a nation determined by the push/pull of good and evil.  The problem is: who decides which is which?  Not everything is as clear-cut as the depradations of ISIS.  Lots of us would consider Dick Cheney, Anthony Scalia and Ted Cruz (among others) as "evil down to (their) depths" but we restrain ourselves from taking the sort of action that Mr. Brooks would advocate with respect to Islamic jihadists and the president of Russia.  For the most part, good and evil exist in the eye (and the mind) of the beholder.  We can't rush off to war strictly on the basis of raw emotion or literary appreciation.

It is not at all hypocritical.  Yes people died at the command of Assad and people are dying now, but certain acts necessarily shock the conscience.  The use of chemical weapons for instance, the targeting of children, the use of rape as a weapon, beheadings, which one imagines, are slow and painful.  These aren't just killings, but acts of barbarism.  It is only human nature to be offended more by one particular act than the other, and if that is hypocrisy, then I guess that makes all of us human beings, hypocrites by nature.

Your history of the Great Recession and the glacial recovery are very accurate but the problem is your advice based on macroeconomic analysis of the 1930s and Japan and current reality was drowned out by the roar of the "deficit hysterics".

As Karen Garcia and Rima Regas wrote, so eloquently, the roar also overcome the pain that our government policies and the greedy, correct that, irrational acts on minimum wage and investments in public goods that could have contributed to the strength of the economy has been ignored and not challenged by the elected representative government of the United States of America.

It has been extremely costly and irrational policy period that John McBride has reminded us costly, "All costs considered the GAO estimates the costs to the nation at a staggering $22 trillion."

Those who are in the 90% and below need to realize that they must express their discontent with the Government's harmful response to the Great Recession, no relief in sight, with this 113th Congress. On November 4, every adult has a chance to express their discontent. Voting D even if you are an underemployed, or non-working adult in a Red State. It will send a strong message to the Congress and strengthen the hand of warriors for fairness like Senators Sanders and Warren. Simply pull the lever for Ds. The D message will do more to stifle those whose roar has drowned out Dr. Ks voice of reason than anything I can think of.

Don't take it anymore, Vote D.

Niall Ferguson plays a very important role in public discourse: He says things which others would feel too embarrassed, too conflicted, or too ashamed to say openly. Things like praising the British Empire despite its brutal exploitation of its colonies, leaving poverty and chaos behind. Or his recommendation that the US should have dropped dozens of nuclear weapons on China during the Korean war. Or his lamenting the (fortunate) fact that the US is incapable of carrying out the kind of colonization he recommends for troubled areas of the world --- not shock and awe but *decades* of occupation.

Niall Ferguson is a red-blooded, two-fisted reactionary, and proud to be one. Hence all the press attention.

A.G.
